docs.lead_paragraph: AT this time of year, the resolve of even the most ardent exerciser can begin to falter. Who wants to jog when streets are icy, or bicycle under a shower of sleet. Not even swimming may beckon when it means stepping out into a cold, dark morning or night. Yet in several ways winter is the most important time to maintain an exercise routine. It is often a time of unwanted expansion - thicker waists, heftier thighs, rounder bellies. Appetites are naturally stimulated by the cold. Since eating and digesting food generate body heat, we often turn to food when we feel cold. The resulting layers of added body fat, so helpful to hibernating and foraging animals like squirrels, make us feel sluggish and less likely to want to exercise. Then there are those New Year's resolutions to start an exercise program. The latest national surveys show that, despite the explosive growth in sales of exercise clothing and equipment, 60 percent of Americans get no regular exercise. When people do exercise, too often it is the result of guilt rather than desire. Without a realistic understanding of what exercise can do for you, resolve tends to fade with the first gust of wintry wind.
